channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: An Afghan national has been identified as the man in custody in the shooting of National Guard members, two people familiar say
item.description: The suspect, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, arrived in the U.S. in 2001 and for a time lived in Washington state.

item.title: Guardsmen shot in D.C. were targeted by attacker and are in critical condition, officials said in updates. Follow our coverage.
item.description: West Virginia Gov. Patrick Morrisey initially said both Guard members were killed, but he later said he was getting “conflicting reports” about their condition. The suspect, who was also wounded, was taken into custody and transported to a hospital, officials said.

item.title: Two West Virginia National Guard members who were shot in D.C. have died, officials say. Police have a suspected shooter in custody.
item.description: “These brave West Virginians lost their lives in the service of their country,” wrote West Virginia Gov. Patrick Morrisey. “We are in ongoing contact with federal officials as the investigation continues.”

item.title: Two National Guardsmen shot near White House. Their conditions are unknown. Follow our coverage.
item.description: The shooting happened at the corner of 17th and H Streets NW, and three gunshot victims were transported to the hospital, according to D.C. Fire and EMS spokesperson Vito Maggiolo.

item.title: Death toll rises to 36 in Hong Kong high-rise fire, with 279 people still missing, official says
item.description: The fire broke out at Wang Fuk Court in Tai Po, a northeastern district in Hong Kong’s New Territories. Rescue efforts have continued into the night. Officials have not yet commented on the cause of the blaze.

item.title: Should I wash my turkey inside and out before stuffing it? Ask our food team your Thanksgiving questions.
item.description: Happening now: Should I wash my turkey inside and out before stuffing it? Ask our food team your Thanksgiving questions.

item.title: Georgia prosecutor ends 2020 election interference case against Trump and his allies
item.description: The racketeering case, brought in 2023, was bogged down by allegations of prosecutorial misconduct.

item.title: This Thanksgiving dish stars in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: At least 13 people dead after huge fire engulfs high-rise buildings in Hong Kong
item.description: Two others were in critical condition, emergency services said. The fire appeared to spread across bamboo scaffolding at Wang Fuk Court in Tai Po.

item.title: Trump wants a bigger White House ballroom. His handpicked architect disagrees.
item.description: President Donald Trump’s desire to go big with the project has put him at odds with architect James McCrery II, who has counseled restraint over concerns that the planned 90,000-square-foot addition could dwarf the 55,000-square-foot mansion.

item.title: FBI and Democrats. Trump ballroom. National parks. Drug pricing. Nuclear start-ups. Campbell’s soup. Screen detox. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro must begin 27-year sentence for coup attempt after he exhausted all appeals, court rules
item.description: In a final ruling, Brazil’s Supreme Court upheld Bolsonaro’s conviction for attempting a coup, attempting the violent abolition of the democratic rule of law and other charges.

item.title: D.C. Mayor Muriel E. Bowser (D) will not run for fourth term, a decision bound to usher in a competitive mayoral race
item.description: Bowser’s seismic decision will bring to a close more than a decade in leadership overseeing some of the city’s most booming times and also its most turbulent crises this century. In an interview Monday night with The Washington Post, Bowser, 53, said that “we’ve accomplished what we set out to accomplish.”

item.title: CDC’s new top deputy had ordered his state health department to stop promoting mass vaccinations amid a flu surge
item.description: Ralph Abraham, who is Louisiana’s surgeon general, has been hired as the principal deputy director at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, according to a spokesperson for the Health and Human Services Department. The CDC currently has no permanent director, so Abraham would essentially be running the agency.

item.title: EPA will abandon air pollution rule that the agency has said would prevent thousands of U.S. deaths
item.description: The Environmental Protection Agency will no longer defend Biden-era limits on fine-particle pollution, which causes heart and lung disease.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: After he postponed wedding, fiancée split and took the sympathy with her
item.description: Carolyn Hax: After he postponed wedding, fiancée split and took the sympathy with her

item.title: Taiwan’s president: I will boost defense spending to protect our democracy
item.description: An unprecedented military buildup by Beijing threatens peace and stability in the region.

item.title: What’s going on with Trump’s gold ‘Oval Office’ sign?
item.description: Online, naysayers have compared the ornate font to the one used in the Cheesecake Factory logo or the fanciful typefaces used to make “Live, Laugh, Love” signs. A White House spokesperson swiped back: “President Trump is making the White House beautiful and giving it the glory it deserves. Only people with a severe case of Trump Derangement Syndrome would find a problem with that.”

item.title: A sudden resignation in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Comey case. Ukraine talks. Oval Office sign. Gaza winter. AI hiring bias. Sleep apnea. Thanksgiving cost. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: The 33 definitive rules of road trips
item.description: A manual for drivers and passengers who want to get along.

item.title: Pentagon says it will investigate Sen. Mark Kelly (D-Arizona) after controversial video
item.description: The announcement Monday follows a viral video posted last week in which Kelly, a combat veteran, and five other Democratic colleagues reminded U.S. service members of their duty to disobey unlawful orders.

item.title: Judge tosses cases against James Comey and Letitia James, rules prosecutor appointment unlawful
item.description: The decision disqualifying Lindsey Halligan as U.S. attorney sets back Trump’s efforts to use the Justice Department to target perceived rivals.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Two affairs and a big lie later, can their marriage be saved?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Two affairs and a big lie later, can their marriage be saved?

item.title: A witness exposes unusual tactics used to prop up mortgage fraud cases
item.description: The witness in the Sen. Adam Schiff (D-California) case exposed surprising revelations about Trump officials and their attempts to reach an indictment.

item.title: Chatting with AI bots in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Gov. Andy Beshear: This slap in the face to rural America is a chance to turn it blue
item.description: Democrats should be the party of aspiration — and talk like normal human beings.

item.title: Jimmy Cliff, Jamaican reggae star with global following, dies at 81
item.description: His lead performance as a singer turned outlaw in the 1972 film “The Harder They Come” helped introduce reggae to the world.

item.title: Ukraine talks. MAGA divide. Power shutoffs. ICE raids. ‘Forever chemicals.’ Cancer screening. Visual effects quiz. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene’s resignation is a sign of a possible turning point for Trump’s term
item.description: Recent developments suggest a potential rebellion within the Republican Party as President Donald Trump struggles with low poll numbers.

item.title: A hulking home addition in Virginia is dividing neighbors and stumping officials
item.description: The construction has driven a split into a leafy neighborhood of mostly one- and two-story homes, and the bad feelings have spilled out into Facebook screeds, awkward encounters and in-person harassment.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent writes: It’s time to end the filibuster
item.description: Senate Republicans should not shy from doing what Democrats are certain to do.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: These people had near-death experiences. Here’s how it changed their lives.
item.description: No experience is exactly the same, but there are some commonly reported features, such as seeing a brilliant light, feeling a sense of peace, or having the sensation of leaving one’s body or being drawn into a tunnel. However it might look, these events can permanently affect a person’s life.

item.title: Spirit falls in NWSL final as Rose Lavelle powers Gotham to title
item.description: The Washington Spirit lost, 1-0, to Gotham FC in the NWSL final Saturday night in San Jose. Gotham won its second title in three years. Washington was seeking its second league championship.

item.title: Ukraine’s Zelensky faces an agonizing choice. David Ignatius has the latest from the Trump administration’s new push for peace.
item.description: U.S. officials tell me Trump’s peace plan is flexible, but a painful decision lies at its core.

item.title: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez built her own political machine. Now she’s deciding her next move.
item.description: Seven years after she leapt onto the national stage as an outsider, the New York Democrat is considering a run for Senate or president and has become one of the party’s most significant leaders.

item.title: White House blew past legal concerns in deadly strikes on drug boats
item.description: The Trump administration sidestepped skeptical lawyers across national security agencies as it pursued a military campaign against alleged narcotraffickers, according to multiple current and former officials familiar with the debates.

item.title: U.N. climate talks fizzle out 10 years after Paris accord
item.description: Nearly 200 countries reached an agreement in Brazil Saturday that makes no mention of curtailing the use of fossil fuels, the main drivers of climate change. The deal represents a win for the oil, gas and coal industries.

item.title: Our top 10 favorite books of the year, as selected by the staff of The Washington Post’s Book World
item.description: The list includes debut novels by Kate Riley and Lucas Schaefer, nonfiction about the American Revolution and women in the Soviet Union, and more.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene announces she is resigning from Congress in the wake of a feud with Trump
item.description: The longtime MAGA supporter says she is stepping down as of Jan. 5.

item.title: Supreme Court justice temporarily pauses order blocking Texas map favoring GOP
item.description: The order will give the high court time to consider an appeal by Texas, which is seeking to overturn the ruling by a panel of federal judges.

item.title: Top FDA drug regulator raises alarms about expediting approvals, arguing they could threaten Americans’ safety
item.description: Richard Pazdur, who assumed his new role this month, has warned that new Trump administration initiatives could be illegal and pose a risk to public health.

item.title: Former U-Va. student given five life sentences in shooting that killed three classmates
item.description: Christopher Darnell Jones Jr. pleaded guilty last year to three counts of first-degree murder in the 2022 shootings on the University of Virginia campus. Two other students were injured.

item.title: Judge blocks IRS from sharing data with DHS for immigration enforcement
item.description: Immigration officials had asked the tax agency for help locating 1.2 million suspected undocumented immigrants in August.

item.title: Trump pivots from bashing Mamdani, predicting he will ‘do a great job’ as New York City’s mayor
item.description: President Donald Trump warmed to Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, even declaring he would finally feel comfortable moving back to the city with the 34-year-old democratic socialist running city hall.

item.title: ‘This is not regime change’: María Corina Machado’s message to Americans
item.description: ‘This is not regime change’: María Corina Machado’s message to Americans

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: Evict ‘at risk’ sister from family home you inherited?
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: Evict ‘at risk’ sister from family home you inherited?
